revisions.rev:
{{Infobox OS | name = CentOS | logo = [[Image:CentOS full logo.svg|200px]] | screenshot = [[Image:CentOS 6.0.png|300px]] | caption = CentOS 6.0's default [[GNOME]] desktop | collapsible = Yes | developer = The CentOS Project | family = [[Unix-like]] | source_model = [[Free and open source software]] | released = {{start date|2004|05|14|03|32|38|Z}}<ref name="CentOS2Announcement" /> | marketing_target = [[Business|Free]] computing ([[Desktop computer|desktop]]s, [[Mainframe computer|mainframes]], [[Server (computing)|server]]s, [[workstation]]s) | frequently_updated = Yes | kernel_type = [[Monolithic kernel|Monolithic]] ([[Linux kernel|Linux]]) | language = [[Multilingualism|Multilingual]] | updatemodel = [[Yellow dog Updater, Modified|Yum]] ([[PackageKit]]) | package_manager = [[RPM Package Manager]] | ui = [[GNOME]] and [[KDE]] (user-selectable) | supported_platforms = [[IA-32|i386]], [[x86-64]], [[PowerPC]], [[s390]], [[s390x]] | license = [[GNU GPL]] & various others. | working_state = Current | website = [http://www.centos.org/ CentOS.org] }}
'''CentOS''' is a [[free software|free]] [[operating system]] based on [[Red Hat Enterprise Linux]] (RHEL). It exists to provide a free enterprise class computing platform and strives to maintain 100% [[binary compatibility]] with its [[Upstream (software development)|upstream]] distribution.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.centos.org/modules/tinycontent/index.php?id=3 | title=Purpose of CentOS | publisher=CentOS Project | accessdate=2009-04-21 }}</ref> CentOS stands for '''C'''ommunity '''ENT'''erprise '''O'''perating '''S'''ystem.
CentOS is the most popular [[Linux distribution]]s for web servers with almost 30% of all Linux web servers using it.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://blogs.computerworld.com/16596/the_most_popular_web_server_linux_is|title=The most popular Linux for Web servers is ...|publisher=computerworld.com|format=blog}}</ref>
== Structure == Red Hat Enterprise Linux is available only through a paid subscription service that provides access to software updates and varying levels of technical support. The product is largely composed of software packages distributed under either an [[open source license|open source]] or a [[free software license]] and the [[source code]] for these packages is made public by Red Hat.
CentOS developers use Red Hat's source code to create a final product very similar to Red Hat Enterprise Linux. Red Hat's branding and logos are changed because [[Red Hat]] does not allow them to be redistributed.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.redhat.com/licenses/rhel_rha_eula.html | title=Red Hat License Agreements | publisher=[[Red Hat]] | accessdate=2008-06-01 }}</ref>
CentOS is available free of charge. Technical support is primarily provided by the community via official mailing lists, web forums, and chat rooms. The project is not affiliated with Red Hat and thus receives no financial or logistical support from the company; instead, the CentOS Project relies on donations from users and organizational sponsors.
== Versioning scheme == CentOS version numbers have two parts, a major version and a minor version. The major and minor version numbers respectively correspond to the major version and update set of Red Hat Enterprise Linux from which the source packages used to build CentOS are taken. For example, CentOS 4.4 is built from the source packages from Red Hat Enterprise Linux 4 update 4.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.centos.org/modules/smartfaq/faq.php?faqid=34 | title=What is the versioning/release scheme of CentOS and how does it compare to the upstream vendor? | publisher=CentOS Project | accessdate=2009-04-21 }}</ref>
Since mid-2006, starting with version 4.4 (formally known as Red Hat Enterprise Linux 4.0 update 4), Red Hat has adopted a versioning convention identical to that of CentOS, e.g., Red Hat Enterprise Linux 4.5.<ref>{{cite web|title=Red Hat Enterprise Linux > AS/ES/WS Basics|url=http://kbase.redhat.com/faq/FAQ_80_10667.shtm|publisher=[[Red Hat]]|accessdate=2008-08-11}}</ref>
== Release history == The architecture information is taken from the [http://www.centos.org/modules/tinycontent/index.php?id=2 CentOS Overview] page.

== Architectures == CentOS supports only the x86 architectures:<ref name="about">{{cite web | url=http://www.centos.org/modules/tinycontent/index.php?id=2 | title=About CentOS | publisher=CentOS | accessdate=2008-06-01 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.redhat.com/rhel/server/details/#architectures | title=Red Hat Enterprise Linux server details | publisher=[[Red Hat]] | accessdate=2008-06-01 }}</ref> * [[IA-32|x86]] (32-bit) * [[x86-64]] (AMD's AMD64 and Intel's EM64T, 64-bit)
The following architectures are not supported by CentOS (as of version 5): * IA-64 (Intel [[Itanium]] architecture, 64-bit) ''(beta support since CentOS 3)'' * [[PowerPC]]/32 ([[Apple Inc.|Apple]] [[Macintosh]] and [[PowerMac]] running the G3 or G4 PowerPC processor) ''(beta support since CentOS 3)'' * [[IBM]] [[Mainframe computer|Mainframe]] ([[eServer]] [[zSeries]] and [[S/390]]) ''(not CentOS 5)'' * [[DEC Alpha|Alpha]] ''(CentOS 4 only)'' * [[SPARC]] ''(beta support since CentOS 3)''
== Bootable media version == *A [[Live CD]] version of CentOS is available at ''mirror.centos.org''. *A [[Live USB]] of CentOS can be created manually or with [[UNetbootin]].
== Tao Linux == {{See also|Red Hat Enterprise Linux derivatives}} '''Tao Linux''' was another prominent distribution derived from Red Hat Enterprise Linux. Its primary developer announced in June 2006 that Tao would be retired and rolled into CentOS development. Tao users migrated to the CentOS release via "yum update".<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.centos.org/modules/news/article.php?storyid=135 | title=Retirement of TaoLinux | publisher=CentOS Project | accessdate=2009-04-21 }}</ref>
== History and organizational difficulties == In July 2009, it was reported that CentOS's founder, Lance Davis, had disappeared in 2008. Davis had ceased contribution to the project but continued to hold the registration for the CentOS domain and PayPal account. In August 2009, the CentOS team reportedly made contact with Davis and obtained the centos.info and centos.org domains.<ref>[http://blogs.zdnet.com/perlow/?p=10790 Perlow, Jason. (2 August 2009). CentOS: Getting Their S#!t Together is a Top Priority. ''ZDNet'']</ref>
{{clear}}
